Package ftc.team6460.javadeck.api.planner

This package contains the classes and code for a full robot motion planner.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ObstacleSensor
    Describes a peripheral that can detect imminent obstacles.
    PositionIntegrator
    Interface for a class that can find likely robot positions.
    RobotPosition
    Describes the position of a robot on the field.
    Sensor
    Describes a peripheral that can determine the probability of the robot to be at any given point on the field.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Goal<T>
    Describes a goal for a motion planner.
    GoalPlanner<T>
    Contains a planner for goals.
    ImmutableRobotPosition
    Describes a robot position, that should not change.
    LocationCandidate
    Describes a candidate location
    LocationCandidate.Comparator  
    RelativePosition
    Describes a position relative to the robot's current position and orientation.
    RobotDrive
    Interface allowing physical robot to be moved to a new position.
    RobotState<T>
    Describes the current state of a robot.
    VolatilePosition
    A temporary, reusable holder for a position value, designed to limit GC pressure.
    WeightedAveragePositionIntegrator
    Calculates the robot's most likely position(s) from a set of sensors.
    WeightedAveragePositionIntegrator.IntPair  
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    ObstacleException
    Thrown if the robot collides with an obstacle during a move, or if any planner operations are illegal due to obstacles.
    RobotHardwareException
    Describes a malfunction of robot hardware, such as a malfunctioning motor, or impossible move0.

Package ftc.team6460.javadeck.api.planner Description

This package contains the classes and code for a full robot motion planner.

Costs and benefits

Costs and benefits should be consistent within each set, however no specific correlation between units of cost and units of benefit needs to be made. A reasonable benefit unit might be the number of competition points scored by the robot for completing this task.

Coordinates

Coordinates should be specified in meters, specifying the center of the robot. Generally, the robot's start position is defined to be on the X-axis, such that (0,0) is located at the leftmost of the field, on the side on which the robot is parked to start. X increases to the right, and Y increases forward (away from this start wall). Theta is defined as the angle between the robot's natural "forward" direction and the positive X-axis, resulting from the conversion of rectangular coordinates (x, y) to polar coordinates (r, theta) in the range of -pi to pi, namely using Math.atan2(double,double). Implementations should accept values outside this range, and may "normalize" them using Math.IEEEremainder(angle, Math.PI*2).

Floating-point error

Standard floating point error of a few ulps is not an issue as the hardware and sensors have far more tolerance on their readings. However, catastrophic rounding should be avoided.
